history.content: Please note that declared math majors do not have enrollment priority during phase 1 or phase 2. Please review this page for more info: https://eecs.berkeley.edu/resources/undergrads/cs/degree-reqs/enrollment-policy

children.subject: If you're 40 on the waitlist, you'll most likely get in. Don't worry..

How do you conclude it's not fair? If you intend to declare Math/CS double major, you should be prepared and know all policies before declaring Math major (or even before transferring to Cal), including the Math/CS enrollment policy. The enrollment policy of both CS lower and Math upper gives priority to new undeclared transfers. All of them are on the department websites. It's your fault for not doing enough researches. It's similar to how you prepared for UC application. 

The admit rate of Math major is approximately four times higher than CS for transfer students but there are no restrictions for non-CS-intended transfers to declare CS. Which do you think is fairer?

^ Way to give a warm welcome to your fellow Berkeley student. Great on you for encouraging people to subvert their academic goals in order to game a flawed system. I also love that you are implying there is a stratified cast system based off of major making some more deserving of classes than others with admit rate as a proxy for deservedness.

OP I'm sorry this is your welcome to Berkeley, not everyone here is like that. Given your waitlist position you will very likely get in. The admins won't explicitly say you will get in bc they can't make you promises. Also, you are right, the priority doesn't make sense. The logic is that undeclared L&S can potentially declare CS but imo it's flawed reasoning bc Math needs 61B for a CS concentration (which is part of the major).

As an EECS major I have run into similar strange priorities. This semester in EE16a 75 seats are saved for EECS majors of all years and 325 seats are saved for L&S Undeclared majors all years. Electrical Engineering is in EECS's names. You get my point.

Not everyone here is like what? None of your understanding to my words is correct. Which sentence above encourages people to subvert their academic goals? Any student willing to declare has the responsibility to plan their prospective coursework ahead instead of complaining the system after he/she fails to declare (or even graduate). You think this system is flawed then I wonder what is a perfect system in your mind? Which sentence above do you feel I'm implying some majors are more deserving than the others? What I don't agree is that some students willing to declare some majors apply for another major with much higher admit rate and eventually they declare the original major they are interested in. Although I cannot agree with such strategies, I am not complaining the admission system is unfair because all the admission information is open to everyone and posted online. Well-prepared applicants should be able to understand such situation before they make the best decisions for themselves.

Back to the enrollment, math department and EECS are two separate departments. It's not EECS department's responsibility to reserve the seats for students from other majors just because they elect to take EE/CS classes as their electives or concentration. The department is kind enough to keep expending the lower division CS classes each semester so that most of the students without enrollment priority can eventually have the spots (if they waitlist themselves early). There is no perfect enrollment policy to make it completely fair to everyone. What the department does is to work hard and try to help everyone willing to take CS classes to be able to enroll. There are not many departments offering advising appointments on CalCentral to all Cal students and also they adjust the enrollment priority every year in order to make it as fair as possible. Also, again, all the EECS enrollment policies are posted (and updated frequently) on either department website or the EECS 101 forum so that all students may plan ahead for having the best chance to enroll.

So even though I am a transfer student, I cannot have priority to choose 61B? I think it's not fair, because my friends who is also a transfer student can choose whatever he want to choose because he did not declare his major this semester. If I did so(not declare any major), I can choose any course without limitation. I do want to double major in math and cs. I am now stay at 40 waiting list in 61B. I am so worry whether I can enroll in this class.
Does CS61B usually take everyone off the waitlist at the end? If so, will the class expand again?

history.content:
Hi professor,

I am a transfer student who declare applied math this semester. I receive the e-mail of expand 61B for transfer student who are in semester 5 or 6. However, I still cannot add to this course. This course is really important for me to declare in cs.

Best 

Dingzhong Hu
history.subject: Tranfer Student in Semester 6 cannot enroll to cs 61B
